notes:
1. Concept

Fluid statics deals with fluids at rest. In a static fluid, the pressure increases with depth. This is because the fluid at a certain depth must support the weight of the fluid above it.

2. Hydrostatic Pressure Equation

The pressure ($P$) at a depth $h$ below the free surface of a liquid is given by:

$$ P = P_0 + \rho g h $$
  • $P$ is the absolute pressure at depth $h$.
  • $P_0$ is the pressure at the free surface (often atmospheric pressure, $P_{atm}$).
  • $\rho$ is the density of the fluid (assumed to be constant).
  • $g$ is the acceleration due to gravity.
  • $h$ is the vertical depth below the surface.

The term $\rho g h$ is the gage pressure at that depth. Gage pressure is the pressure relative to the local atmospheric pressure.

3. Key Principles

  • Pressure acts perpendicular to any surface it contacts.
  • The pressure at any two points at the same elevation in a continuous body of fluid at rest is the same.

solvedExamples.question: What is the gage pressure at a depth of 10 meters in water? (Use $\rho_{water} = 1000$ kg/m³ and $g=9.81$ m/s²).
solvedExamples.explanation: Gage pressure is calculated as $P_{gage} = \rho g h$. $P_{gage} = (1000 \text{ kg/m³})(9.81 \text{ m/s²})(10 \text{ m}) = 98100 \text{ Pa} = 98.1$ kPa.

solvedExamples.question: An open tank contains water with a layer of oil (density 800 kg/m³) on top. If the oil layer is 2 m deep and the water layer is 3 m deep, what is the gage pressure at the bottom of the tank?
solvedExamples.explanation: The total pressure is the sum of the pressure from the oil and the pressure from the water. $P_{total} = P_{oil} + P_{water} = (\rho_{oil}gh_{oil}) + (\rho_{water}gh_{water})$. $P_{total} = (800)(9.81)(2) + (1000)(9.81)(3) = 15696 + 29430 = 45126$ Pa, or 45.1 kPa.
